post_title: A Head Start On Indian Summer
post_text:
God, I love the Fall, especially the days of Indian Summer.  It's coming;  I can already see some not-so-subtle changes in the leaves of some of the trees.   Like invisible clockwork, it will start in earnest in September.  First the kids will return to school; then the evenings will turn crispy-cool; then the red and yellow hues will gradually transform the tree-scape. On any given evening, a high school band will be heard playing at a football game somewhere 'over there', many neighborhood blocks away, through air subtly suffused with the scent of burning wood from back yard chimnias.     
     As far as I'm concerned, there's no better time to make new friends or to perhaps even find one's soul mate.  If you're between 35-45 and love the Fall as much as I do, feel free to write back.  Perhaps we could enjoy the color change together.  I'm single, easy to look at, around your age, a self employed homeowner, a lover of God and life.

When it comes to Craigslist ads, people can get a little too picky about what they want. For example, some gal on the W4M board said she wanted "no mullets". I'm thinking she probably turned off about 100 otherwise-perfect guys who just happened to have longish hair. To avoid such nonsense, I've devised a point-rating system, whereby each thing I like or don't like in a prospective mate is given a point rating. That way I don't accidentally chase off an awesome person over some little personal preference. 
The rules of the game are simple - you read the ad, tally up your points, and email me if you like your score.

You're between 25 and 36 - add 5 points

You meet people halfway - add 8 points. 
You're environmentally aware, and are generally conscientious about things - add 9 points. 
You have brunette hair - add 2 points. 
You hair is some wild color like construction-vest orange - subtract 8 points. 
You wear lots of jewelry, makeup, and perfume - subtract 5 points. 
You have a long life ahead of you - add 5 points. 
You don't mind debating and getting to the bottom of things - add 5 points. 
You read romance novels - subtract 5 points. 
You read the Tao Te Ching and liked it - add 9 points. 
You like Seinfeld, Mark Twain, Woody Allen, or Breaking Bad - add 4 points for each. 
You're Republican - subtract 7 points 
Religious - subtract 6 points 
Anal retentive - subtract 3.47 points 
You wouldn't mind dating a fitness trainer - add 10 points.

You're still reading this? - add 5 points.

Ok, put your pencils down, the test is over. Please tally up your points and forward them to me, along with a photograph and where you think a cool place to go for a first date would be. post_title: We're not looking for love or romance, just the cure for boredom.
post_text:
The Enlightened of Highlands/The Heartland needs and wants you! 
Come help us elevate humanity to a higher level as we continue to evolve in an AUGMENTED REALITY GAME!
Are you bored and looking to meet funny, smart people who like to get out and have fun, especially in the Highlands County area? 
We are a small group of "agents" involved with Ingress, a massive multiplayer location-based alternative reality game. It is currently played by millions of people across the globe. Many local Enlightened agents have attended college and are quite literate, but a post high school education is not required. You must have an open mind, be forward thinking and enjoy games with a strong science fiction backstory. Ingress is a very social game that relies heavily on teamwork, although we play out in the field alone or in pairs much of the time. The ability to plan, strategize, communicate and work well with others are all highly desired traits we're seeking in good potential agents. We enjoy getting together and hanging out and are becoming good friends.
There is another faction that we play against. Do not be fooled by them. The role of the Resistance, according to the game, is to stop the alien incursion. They claim to be protecting the human race when they are actually fearful of any sort of change and dislike people or things that are different. The Resistance in this region doesn't particularly understand the basic premise the game, which is sad because the story is complex, rich and full of endless potential. 
Come join us! We'll help you get started and make sure you have the necessary tools. All you need is an Android Smartphone or an iPhone, a data plan, your own transportation (car, bike, scooter, cycle, skateboard - whatever you use to get around) and a strong desire to get out and make new friends. Follow instructions on the poster to join our local community, or scan the QR code.
You don't need to be technically savvy or a computer genius to play. 
For more information, check out http://www.ingress.com
See you soon! We look forward to meeting you and making you part of our growing team!
WARNING: It is highly addictive!

post_title: This is my everything; and this is my Letter.
post_text:
Here it is. 4:35am. Dawn is a whisper away behind hastily closed shades. My room is basked in the light of two screens: a neglected television and the monitor before me.
I'm just going to write. This is everything I have. Soul laid raw like a bared spitting wire. If you're reading this, maybe you're who I'm looking for. Do I know you? No. Do I know who I need, what I need, or even the right questions to ask? No. But you might.
I'm in my very early 30s. I'm trapped. The claws of both ends of the spectrum are in me, pulling me apart. I need adventure, I need nights of electric magic where the world is set aside. And I need to be responsible and pull this trainwreck back on the rails. I know the grown up way to do things, I know the mature and sensible path, I know all the "I should" roads and why I should avoid the other ones...but I guess I'm still young enough to still have a little hope that I won't be placed in one of those mundane grooves. Young enough to not care...or perhaps old enough that I don't care anymore? Who knows.
I'm a mess. Polluted with cigarettes and alcohol, mind hazed with anxiety and depression. On the precipice of a perpetual existential crisis. I'm a writer no one reads. A comedian no one laughs at. A model no one photographs. I'm a traveler of the world beneath: the undercultures and the paranormal, the occult and the strange. Yet I can tap dance through high society with appropriate smile on my face, all firm handshakes and practiced laughs. Physically, I'm fit, I like to imagine I'm decent looking, I take care of myself. I don't do drugs, not even pot. I don't know if I like to party because I haven't had the opportunity - but I don't think I like it much. I like bar hopping, I like clubs, I like throwing myself into the night and seeing where I wind up.
I need to be out there, but I'm always in here. In this room. Broke. Unemployed, and not for a lack of looking. First time in my life that I'm not the provider, than I'm not the one bringing in income and supporting myself and making something of myself. Everything I'll ever be spans from here, and where will I take it? I'm paralyzed night and again. Around me stretches an ethereal and grand network of friends. You already know me better than they do. I'm married.
This is a complaint. A whine. A rant I have no place making. I'm not starving or freezing, not ill or mad. Yet here I am. Emptying myself on the internet. On craigslist, of all places. Emptying myself to you. They tell me not to believe it - not to indulge in guilt, not to see a burden in the mirror. I know not to. But I don't know what I see.
Where was my adventure? Where was my magic? I didn't want money or power or anything. Just those. I chase them in alleys and bars and clubs, I chase them on the internet and on blank pages. More often than not, I'm swallowing anxiety medication with beer in a bar bathroom. I come out all smile and charm for my friends. I make them laugh, I give them what they expect.
Every corner I turn, a sliver of me expects to see that pair of eyes that change my life forever. Every time I look up from my drink, I expect to happen into that serendipity that changes it all. I expect to find my magic portal, my stairway to high society, my hand guiding me through the night.
A trashy pop song comes on. Everyone dances. The song is about forgetting the day and ignoring tomorrow; about being yourself and being free until dawn. I connect with the trashy pop song more than I have with another human that week.
My tastes in all of the above are varied - one night I may be listening to triphop or old punk at home while sipping absinthe and reading an old occult grimoire, and the next night I might be having a beer and head-bobbing to thumping trashy modern club music at the bar while paying half-attention to a football game on television. I like the outdoors, I like hiking, I like exploring out-of-the-way places and faraway places and all that jazz. I can go from tromping through the woods to suit and tie dinners with political royalty with ease; I can look like I belong in an old school goth hangout or some trendy downtown club or anywhere in between - and generally speaking, I can get along with anyone at any of those places.
I never sewed my oats. I know that's part of it. Maybe more than part, maybe less. Didn't get out to much, didn't get to experience much, didn't get to really sew my wild oats. I entered my current relationship when I was still too young to even hit a bar. In quick fashion, I stepped from 'controlled family life' to 'serious relationship' life - with no transition between. This may sound great -I know it sounds great, in fact- but if you scratch past the surface I guess you can see one of the issues pretty clearly: there's a 'finding yourself' period most people go through, and I never got it. Even if it's a painful experience for a lot of folks, it's something that helps define them and prepare them for what's to come. I skipped that part and never looked back. Maybe that's what's catching up with me now. Boo-hoo, you say. Deal with it, you say.
I can't, apparently. Sue me.
"You may not have anyone else, you say, but you're married!" you say. "Open up to your wife," you say.
You know how if you have a container of liquid that's sealed, and you poke just a tiny hole in it - and only a trickle can come out? But then if you open another hole somewhere else, it can pour out a lot more freely? I don't have any other place to really turn and vent. My friends can't handle it or don't want to, I can't begin to afford therapy and the like(nor do I really want to go that route), and so...well, here I am on craigslist at 5:18am.
Out I go. I flirt with girls. I don't cheat, but I feel myself pining for those thrills of 'the hunt' and burgeoning romance and one-night thrills that I've either never had, or haven't felt in many years. A part of me screams at me night after night that I just need a good 'fling' - and you know what's the funny part? I have a "hall pass", for lack of a better term. I just don't know where to start. I haven't just been out of the game for a long time - I was never a player in it to begin with. Cue people emailing me to tell me I'm an awful person for this paragraphs admissions. Don't bother folks, I'm an awful person for lots of better reasons, I'm sure.
I'm the guy with solutions who solves things. In any job I've had, I wind up at some level of 'in charge' immediately, and I tend to be the one to decide the whens/wheres in social outings. I help people when they're down or in a slump or whatever. Shoulder to cry on. Strong arm to get you to a cab. Brows pinched in concern when you seem down.
But when I need help? I'm clueless. I'm not supposed to need help and have no clue where to get it. Aside from anonymously on craigslist; sigh. But sometimes I think that it's just what I need - that spark in someone else. And I could tell my lover or my friends this - but that sort of defeats the purpose, no? I don't want someone helping me only via following my instructions on how to help me, if that makes any sense. If it doesn't, that's okay.
So I'm saying something I've never actually said - and something I may never say with my actual voice, but I'll say it with words on a screen:
I need help.
So here it is, my message in a bottle. To you. Who are you? You're someone who managed to read all this. You understand. You see something in this ridiculous fucking wall of text that I already regret writing. You know something I don't. Maybe you're that beautiful stranger that's going to appear out of the night, grab my hand, and say "Relax, I'm going to get you through this". I hope so.

post_title: I can almost see you out there; I hope you see me.
post_text:
Let me preface all this with one thing, and I only ask you at least read it through: I'm not your prince charming. Please don't misunderstand - I'm not some pickup artist or 'redpiller' here trying to play the cool bad guy angle on you. I'm not some quasi-mythical bad boy archetype stepping out of the ether, all swagger and confidence and smoldering eyes. It certainly doesn't mean I'm coming at you like a slab of meat or a prey animal or a trophy. Indeed, there's no disrespect here - very much the opposite. You deserve to have it all laid out, raw like a bare wire spitting into the night. So, why am I not the one to sweep you off your feet? I'm not good for you. I'm polluted, toxic, taken: a real fucking mess. Plenty more, too, which I'll go into with the rest of all this.
Alright then. Still with me? I hope so. Let's go.
I suppose we'll start with the title of this, right? Appropriately vague and mysterious enough to catch your attention; unless it was just the location - in which case, I should warn you that the verbosity of this won't be fading. Again, for reasons I'll make clear somewhere in the depths of this.
Anyway, the title. Excuse the poetic nonsense for what it is - but sometimes I look out the windshield or the window or into a crowd or into nothing at all and I swear I can damn near make her out. Make -you- out, maybe. Not so much a physical thing as a mental one, as this person who steps out of the night and blows into my life like a wrecking ball. Just around some dim corner, just inside that jazzy little nightclub I drove by, just passing by on the highway - a tantalizing, infuriating little notion.
But before I go any deeper into who I hope you are; I think it's time I give you me. All of me. I owe you that.
You start off these miniature autobiographies with the basic stats, right? I'm 31(nearing 32 within weeks), located obviously in the Lehigh Valley region of PA, and here's a big one - married. I imagine you may have "early mid life crisis" or "just wants a wild fling" floating around somewhere in your head at that, but whomever you are? I don't want you to be a crisis or a fling. So what is it? Why am I here, going on and on in this post? I write. I love to write. Worth noting is that I can only write when I'm some degree of miserable - so here we are, me at about 5am typing away for you, full of a cocktail caffeine and nicotine and alcohol and anxiety medication and headache medicine. Don't misinterpret this as incoherent things fueled by these substances, things soon to be regretted and deleted. I'm lucid and I need to be right where I am to write this. Raw.
In no particular order, here is me. Born and raised in politics and upper-middle-class polite society, driven through religious school and groomed to chit chat with rooms full of suits and showy smiles and firm handshakes. Presented with all a growing boy could really want; certainly too much for me not to feel more than a bit shitty for bemoaning it all online. Limits were there, though - travel, adventure, friendships, girls; these were something for another time.
I'm at a quiet little 20's speakeasy themed bar, sipping a mixed drink named after a poet and soaking in the dim, smooth ambiance. Moments later my circle of loose friends is deciding on different surroundings, and the hours ahead are a rush of dives and sports bars and thumping clubs and me fitting in just well enough that no one notices I don't fit. I'm a social chameleon now, just giving them the laughs and stories they need before retreating outside to answer a pretend phone call.
I'm walking in New York City at 3am, slipping out of the hotel and lighting up a cigarette I only smoke if drinking or out on such a roam. I'm listening to wistful jazz drift from some hidden spot and as I hunt, I never quite find it. I imagine classy people, each one a novel of stories and passion, all looking and talking like it's an artsy old film no one will see. I imagine sultry vocals set upon the backdrop of the music, a smiling barkeep shooting me a wink when I manage to stumble on their secret rendezvous. I imagine a lot; I never find the music. It fades, I do, it's one more drink and off to bed.
I haven't had a best friend in fifteen years, likely more. I have friends - quite a few. You know the cliche I'm about to say already: they don't know me; don't care to. Don't, in many cases, have the ability to. That's fine.
Married. Together well over a decade. Happy. This isn't about unhappy marriages. We meet before I can step foot in a bar, things happen and we're living together and by the time I'm in my mid-twenties, I can't remember a 'me' anymore, just an 'us'. I look back and realize I never figured out who 'me' was.
So. Me. Writer. Model. Journalist. Comedian. Activist. Theologian. Bibliophile. On and on. Words I know grab attention, words that prop me up. Mostly holly. Writer? Sure, I write. No one reads. Journalist? No such thing these days. Comedian? No one's laughing at the real jokes. Model? Sure, all the time. Not many folks throwing money to take pictures of me, though.
Here I am, from coddled life to cossetted life. No chance to make mistakes, no shot at adventure and thrills and all those wild things. Restless and content. Young enough to burn for more, old enough to appreciate what's here.
I talk to my wife about it. She knows. She supports. She pushes me. Go sow your oats, she says - believe it or not. So I go, I flirt, and I'm honest. Nothing happens...and none of it has the bite. None of it has magic. And maybe it'd help if it did, but I don't know anymore. I reveal this to anonymous people online and receive lectures on the nature of marriage.
Here I am, dawn's cracking through the window now and I want to sleep so much. A nest of insomnia, anxiety, and occasional depression. An existential crisis in a man suit - and damn I can wear it well when I want to, and I DO want to...but when? Where? Why?
Here I am, the friend that's a friend when a shoulder or a ride or advice is needed. The responsible one, the good one, the honest one. The one no one drifts too close to - and that's plenty my fault, make no mistake. Here I am, unemployed and unable to support as I always have from my mid-teens. Here I am, a drain - contributing nothing but, perhaps, this amusement to your eyes. Here I am; weak.
Here I am, neglected tv basking me in the blue light of an old movie while the harsh light of the laptop lasts just long enough for this message in a bottle to hit the internet.
That's all me. Now, what about you? I don't know the answers I'm looking for. I don't even know the questions to ask. I do know one thing - a thing I'm loathe to admit. I thing I never could admit, never was allowed, never allowed myself: I need help. Your help. I'm so turned around in my head that I don't know where else to go or what else to say. I talk about magic and moments and electric...and all that's so integral that it goes without saying. What I need? A hand from the darkness, taking mine and yanking me out - not giving up and demanding "I'm gonna get you through this." with a wink and a smile that makes it all okay.
That's all. Thank you for reading this...this disjointed mess. I'd put a finer point on it all if I could, but this is all I have. I lay myself before you, weary and restless. I hope you see me.

post_title: This is my everything; and this is my Letter to You.
post_text:
Here it is. 4:55am. Dawn is a whisper away behind hastily closed shades. My room is basked in the light of two screens: a neglected television and the monitor before me.
I'm just going to write. This is everything I have. Soul laid bare as best I can; revealed to you as I thrust my hand into the ether of the internet. If you're reading this, maybe you're who I'm looking for. Do I know you? No. Do I know who I need, what I need, or even the right questions to ask? No. But you might.
I'm not young, I'm not old. I'm trapped. The claws of both ends of the spectrum are in me, pulling me apart. I need adventure, I need nights of electric magic where the world is set aside. And I need to be responsible and pull this trainwreck back on the rails. I know the grown up way to do things, I know the mature and sensible path, I know all the "I should" roads and why I should avoid the other ones...but I guess I'm still young enough to still have a little hope that I won't be placed in one of those mundane grooves. Young enough to not care...or perhaps old enough that I don't care anymore? Who knows.
I'm a mess. Polluted with cigarettes and alcohol, mind hazed with anxiety and depression. On the precipice of a perpetual existential crisis. I'm a writer no one reads. A comedian no one laughs at. A model no one photographs. I'm a traveler of the world beneath: the undercultures and the paranormal, the occult and the strange. Yet I can tap dance through high society with appropriate smile on my face, all firm handshakes and practiced laughs. Physically, I'm fit, I like to imagine I'm decent looking, I take care of myself. I don't do drugs, not even pot. I don't know if I like to party because I haven't had the opportunity - but I don't think I like it much. I like bar hopping, I like clubs, I like throwing myself into the night and seeing where I wind up.
I need to be out there, but I'm always in here. In this room. Broke. Unemployed, and not for a lack of looking. First time in my life that I'm not the provider, than I'm not the one bringing in income and supporting myself and making something of myself. Everything I'll ever be spans from here, and where will I take it? I'm paralyzed night and again. Around me stretches an ethereal and grand network of friends. You already know me better than they do. I'm married.
This is a complaint. A whine. A rant I have no place making. I'm not starving or freezing, not ill or mad. Yet here I am. Emptying myself on the internet. On craigslist, of all places. Emptying myself to you. They tell me not to believe it - not to indulge in guilt, not to see a burden in the mirror. I know not to. But I don't know what I see.
Where was my adventure? Where was my magic? I didn't want money or power or anything. Just those. I chase them in alleys and bars and clubs, I chase them on the internet and on blank pages. More often than not, I'm swallowing anxiety medication with beer in a bar bathroom. I come out all smile and charm for my friends. I make them laugh, I give them what they expect.
Every corner I turn, a sliver of me expects to see that pair of eyes that change my life forever. Every time I look up from my drink, I expect to happen into that serendipity that changes it all. I expect to find my magic portal, my stairway to high society, my hand guiding me through the night.
A trashy pop song comes on. Everyone dances. The song is about forgetting the day and ignoring tomorrow; about being yourself and being free until dawn. I connect with the trashy pop song more than I have with another human that week.
My tastes in all of the above are varied - one night I may be listening to triphop or old punk at home while sipping absinthe and reading an old occult grimoire, and the next night I might be having a beer and head-bobbing to thumping trashy modern club music at the bar while paying half-attention to a football game on television. I like the outdoors, I like hiking, I like exploring out-of-the-way places and faraway places and all that jazz. I can go from tromping through the woods to suit and tie dinners with political royalty with ease; I can look like I belong in an old school goth hangout or some trendy downtown club or anywhere in between - and generally speaking, I can get along with anyone at any of those places.
I never sewed my oats. I know that's part of it. Maybe more than part, maybe less. Didn't get out to much, didn't get to experience much, didn't get to really sew my wild oats. I entered my current relationship when I was still too young to even hit a bar. In quick fashion, I stepped from 'controlled family life' to 'serious relationship' life - with no transition between. This may sound great -I know it sounds great, in fact- but if you scratch past the surface I guess you can see one of the issues pretty clearly: there's a 'finding yourself' period most people go through, and I never got it. Even if it's a painful experience for a lot of folks, it's something that helps define them and prepare them for what's to come. I skipped that part and never looked back. Maybe that's what's catching up with me now. Boo-hoo, you say. Deal with it, you say.
I can't, apparently. Sue me.
"You may not have anyone else, you say, but you're married!" you say. "Open up to your wife," you say.
You know how if you have a container of liquid that's sealed, and you poke just a tiny hole in it - and only a trickle can come out? But then if you open another hole somewhere else, it can pour out a lot more freely? I don't have any other place to really turn and vent. My friends can't handle it or don't want to, I can't begin to afford therapy and the like(nor do I really want to go that route), and so...well, here I am on craigslist at 5:18am.
Out I go. I flirt with girls. I don't cheat, but I feel myself pining for those thrills of 'the hunt' and burgeoning romance and one-night thrills that I've either never had, or haven't felt in many years. A part of me screams at me night after night that I just need a good 'fling' - and you know what's the funny part? I have a "hall pass", for lack of a better term. I just don't know where to start. I haven't just been out of the game for a long time - I was never a player in it to begin with. Cue people emailing me to tell me I'm an awful person for this paragraphs admissions. Don't bother folks, I'm an awful person for lots of better reasons, I'm sure.
I'm the guy with solutions who solves things. In any job I've had, I wind up at some level of 'in charge' immediately, and I tend to be the one to decide the whens/wheres in social outings. I help people when they're down or in a slump or whatever. Shoulder to cry on. Strong arm to get you to a cab. Brows pinched in concern when you seem down.
But when I need help? I'm clueless. I'm not supposed to need help and have no clue where to get it. Aside from anonymously on craigslist; sigh. But sometimes I think that it's just what I need - that spark in someone else to take me by the hand and say "Alright, look, I'm going to get you through this.". And I could tell my lover or my friends this - but that sort of defeats the purpose, no? I don't want someone helping me only via following my instructions on how to help me, if that makes any sense. If it doesn't, that's okay.
So I'm saying something I've never actually said - and something I may never say with my actual voice, but I'll say it with words on a screen:
I need help.
My soul laid bare. That was it. There's plenty more, I'm sure, but I'll stop now as it's 5:30am and time to lay and watch old movies and hope for sleep. Goodnight. If this touched you in any way, I'll be hoping despite myself to find an email waiting for me. Wreck me, save me, help me, I don't know.

Hello! and welcome! My name is Joe! 29 years old. I am looking for a REAL relationship or the potential for one. So here is my story.. as long as it is.. I will try to sum it all up into a lot of a few words just for you!! I am also looking for friends all over the country but below I am going to talk about what I am looking for in a relationship.
I was born in Ohio and that is where I currently "live". I have been traveling for my job for almost 2 years now. I am currently in Indiana overseeing some work here. I have been here for several months with short trips home to Ohio every so often. I travel most of the eastern United States and Canada but chose to stay in southern Indiana to deal with the biggest challenges for my company. I work a lot and due to my lack of freedom I am scouting all over the country for a new job, as well as a serious relationship. Ideally I would like to move back out west.
My passion is traveling. I have not been across seas yet but hope to find a new job with the freedom that will allow me to do so. I love seeing new places and things and exploring, especially the unknown. I have lived in southern Florida as well as western Colorado. I am currently prospecting Wyoming as my future home, but there are no set plans. I would rather make those plans with a significant other. If you would like to know more about a FEW of my interests then please see the list of them on my profile. I enjoy most of what the world has to offer as long as it doesn't get me in trouble!
I do not smoke, drink, or do drugs. Those things and that lifestyle is 6 years in my past. I have no desire to go back to it seeing as I enjoy my life today more than I did then. I am hard working and I can provide for myself. I do not own my home, I rent it (more of an overpriced storage unit considering I have slept in my bed maybe 2 weeks total this year haha!). I have no desire to buy my own home and settle until I find the woman that actually wants the real deal and lasting relationship. I just got out of a 1 year long relationship. Enough was never enough for her and the lies on top of that were enough. I do not enjoy being lied to, nor do I lie to someone I care about, or lie in general for that matter. I am an honest, caring and loving man and I look for the same in a woman. I enjoy the outdoors and anything to do with it. You can consider me a country boy, raised on a small farm. I do not like living in the city but enjoy the city life occasionally. That brings me to say I am a city slicker cowboy! Ok.. so I thought it sounded good anyway! Oh, I should probably mention my biggest flaw, the thinning of my hair... so if your idea of a "good man" is one with hair, chances are in another 20 years I probably won't have any at all. I understand we all have our preference, but I need a woman with a little more sense, who wants me for more than my hair lol.
So what kind of woman am I looking for? Well.. as simple as it may sound, it is one of the rarest breeds there is I think! I am looking for a woman that enjoys traveling, seeing new places and things, but most of all.. enjoying it WITH ME. Someone who does not want me for my wallet, or because I own 4 cars (soon to sell 2 of them). If you are materialistic then you are not my kind of woman. I like having things, I work my life away to have what little I do have at the moment. I would be fascinated, happy and content if I found a woman that at least worked half as hard as I do! Someone with a sense of humor, has a drivers license, and a job or the willingness to work at the least. Must be open to the idea of relocating, and probably more than once, it just comes with the passion for traveling. It may or may not happen. I do know that I am not going to live in Ohio and am currently looking for a job in Wyoming (no set plans yet). Anyway.. back to what kind of woman I am looking for. Someone who loves spending time together. I am not lazy, I like to do what I can while I am still alive. I do enjoy relaxing and watching movies. I am looking for someone who is in shape, who can handle extensive outdoor activity occasionally like hiking and possibly rock climbing. (There is a lot I want to do that I have not done). Someone similar to my build. Height does not matter. I don't mind if you drink but it must be responsibly.. I do not like women who get drunk and hang all over everyone and make poor choices. I do not want to date a smoker, if you smoke you must be willing to quit. Absolutely no drug use, no if ands or buts and that includes marijuana. I have dealt with all of these things in relationships and the relationships do not work to their full potential with these things involved. IF any of this sounds like you, by all means send me a message! I am a friends with everyone kind of person, I do not judge, I just know what I want and need. IF you are just looking to make a new friend, then I am all for that! I'll talk to anyone.
I do not cheat, I do not lie, I am 100% infinity faithful to the woman I invest my time and effort into. (I was tired of being accused of having another girlfriend in my recent relationship but these are stories to tell later. If you ask, I will tell. I have nothing to hide)
If you REALLY want to get to know me then I can elaborate on my life, you might have to give me at least the next 30 years of your life for me to be able to tell you all the things I have been through, done and dealt with. I have made my mistakes in life (nothing to horrible) and I have learned from those and applied what I learned to my life. People have stolen from me, used me, lied to me, screwed me over, you name it. I have a lifetime of stories to tell but generally will only tell to those who want to listen and laugh a little with me. I should probably mention that considering I am looking all over North America for my ultimate match.. I am willing to meet anyone and everyone, distance is no matter to me considering I love traveling. Who knows, I might be coming through your way in my next adventure. I am at this time planning a trip to Wyoming in the next month or so (late September early Octoberish) although I would hope to find someone to join me in that journey (unless you are already in Wyoming)
So if you are a woman that has a passion for traveling.. wants to see as much of the world as possible and you enjoy the outdoors and anything to do with it then by all means send me a message and we can see where it goes. You can ask me anything your heart so desires. I have nothing to hide. Now, you do not have to be interested in every itty bitty thing that I am.. but I would hope you would want to learn about those things and be involved and interested in them as I would be in the things you enjoy. Families reunited
Two fathers meet with abused children removed from Kenmore home
By John Higgins
Beacon Journal staff writer
The strange family reunion took place in a medical clinic with nurses, social workers, a lawyer, and fathers and children who hadn't seen one another in years. (YEARS OF FATHERS ACCUSED OF PHYSICAL/EMOTIONAL ABUSE TO ROWELS & THE CHILDREN. THIS WOMAN WENT FROM MAN TO MAN BEING ABUSED & THEN PICKS A ONE-IN-A-MILLION, WOMAN WHO DOES THE SAME? ).
The Summit County Children Services Board organized the Thursday meeting to gather medical information about five boys and one girl, ages 6 through 14, removed from their Kenmore home last week.
So began the long process of sorting out what should happen with the children, whose stories of abuse -- as well as the agency's admitted failure to act sooner -- have outraged the Akron community.
The biological fathers, who each have a complicated custody history with the children, could not provide much medical information because they haven't seen them in so long. (ABANDONED CHILDREN).
Darrell ``Butch'' Shaffer Jr., father of the two eldest boys, said it was their first reunion in three years. The boys also asked to see Shaffer's fiancee, Heather McMillen, who hopes the boys can be part of their wedding next month.  (LOOK HE HAS A FIANCEE, BUT HAVE NOT VISITED/CHECKED ON THE CHILDREN FOR 3 YEARS.  OBVIOUS WHERE PRIORITY LIES).
``I was heartbroken, and at the same time my blood was boiling,'' McMillen said. ``When they gave me hugs, you felt their spine and their ribs. They were all up on us giving us hugs and kisses. They were so happy. Their mom told them that we tore our house down and moved away.''
Shaffer and McMillen also saw the 6-year-old, whom police found locked in a bedroom when they removed the children from their home April 28.
``He's as big as my 2-year-old. He's really little, but he looked to be the healthiest one there. (The 14-year-old) wears the same size shoes that my 8-year-old does -- size 5,'' McMillen said.
She said the boys wanted to talk about what had happened to them in the home of their mother, Mary Rowles, and her domestic partner, Alice Jenkins.
Rowles and Jenkins were arrested Friday and charged with several felonies, including child endangering.
A CSB worker told Shaffer and McMillen if they discussed the case with the children at all, the visit would end. This is standard CSB policy.
``They wanted to come home that day,'' McMillen said. ``(The oldest boy) told the caseworker, `Pack us up; we're going home with Mom and Dad right now.' '' (WHY ARE THEY IN A FOSTER HOME AT THIS TIME? STILL? DEADBEAT, WORTHLESS FATHERS.  IT IS REALLY TOO EASY TO INSERT YOUR PRIVATE PARTS & MAKE BABIES, IT IS A REAL MAN WHO SPENDS TIME WITH & SUPPORTS CHILDREN, PHYSICALLY & EMOTIONALLY.)
Brady Postlethwaite was able to see his daughter for a few minutes and gave her a book on dogs that was supposed to be her Christmas present in 2001. He had last seen her Nov. 16, 2001.
She had been living with her mother then.
``Her mom would not allow her to keep it, so my mother-in-law kept it,'' Brady Postlethwaite's wife, Lisa Postlethwaite, said. ``We've kept it all this time because we knew that we would see her again.''
The girl brightened when her father gave her the book again Thursday.
``She grabbed it and opened it up and said, `I remember this' '' he said.
Authorities do not know who the fathers of the other two boys are.
Children's welfare
Now life becomes complicated for everyone.
The same social service agency that failed to intervene despite years of repeated calls now is charged with recommending what should happen next. (NOT THE DR COURT).
``At this point, our focus is on the (immediate) welfare of the children now,'' said CSB spokeswoman Louise Miller on Friday.
The children have all received physicals and have been placed in foster care. Four of the boys are in one home. The other boy and the girl are in separate foster homes.  (WHERE ARE THE FATHERS? )
The siblings will get to visit one other, but coordinating visits with fathers and other relatives is still being worked out.
Rowles and Jenkins -- who posted bond Saturday and were released from the Summit County Jail -- are not permitted any contact with the children, Miller said. (GOOD !)
The children eventually will be enrolled in school. Rowles removed at least three of the children a year ago, and authorities believe all the children were supposedly being taught at home.
``Since they haven't been in school, you have to assess what their knowledge level and needs are,'' Miller said.
Sorting out who would provide the best home for the children won't be an easy task. Shaffer and Ronnie Stuart, the father of the 6-year-old boy, have some criminal convictions -- mostly stemming from their relationships with Rowles.  (CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS, NOT SAFE HOMES FOR THESE CHILDREN. ABANDONED THE CHILDREN & NOT FIT -- THAT IS WHY THEY ARE IN 3 SEPARATE FOSTER HOMES & NOT TOGETHER).
Stuart was not allowed to visit with his son Thursday.  
Stuart's wife, Angie Stuart, said a CSB worker told them the boy had no memory of his father, who hasn't seen his son since the boy was 3 months old. (ABANDONED).
Ronnie Stuart was in prison for some of those years, but even after his release, he says his attorney advised him to steer clear of Rowles if he wanted to avoid false accusations.  (PRISON. NOT A FIT FATHER).
His son doesn't know him.
``They say he is confused, and he does not know his dad. So they want to give him some time to adjust,'' Angie Stuart said.
Ronnie Stuart's history includes drug abuse, and he must prove he's overcome those problems, she said.  (NOT A FIT FATHER).
The fathers say they were asked to provide names of relatives who might care for the boys if CSB decides that placement with the biological fathers while the case is pending is not suitable.
A series of Juvenile Court hearings beginning May 23 will begin the process of deciding what is in the best interest of the children.
Coping with abuse
But the real work will take a long time.
``You're looking at years of help for those kids, not just with psychotherapy, but with a lot of really great parenting,'' said Charles Vehlow, executive director of the Akron-based Child Guidance Centers.
Children in such situations develop defenses that help protect their young, fragile minds from the world they're experiencing.
``Sometimes they believe they're at fault and they deserve whatever they're getting,'' Vehlow said. ``The caretaker has convinced them that what's happening is normal, and it's clearly not normal.''
Akron police said some of the boys had mixed feelings about the arrest of their mother and the woman they were told to call ``Dad.''
Some children play down what has occurred like it's no big deal. They might say: ``I don't mind eating this stuff; I don't mind sleeping on the floor. This isn't so bad,'' Vehlow said.
And they might prefer the home they know, no matter how bad, to a future in strangers' homes they can't imagine will be any better.
Still, some of the children knew that their treatment wasn't normal.
The 8-year-old boy -- hospitalized because he weighed only 28 pounds -- does not have any eyelashes because he pulled them all out, according to court documents.
``He states that he bangs his head against the wall. (He) stated that he would like a better life and that he does not want this bad life anymore.''

An update on abuse case in my area
â¢  Posted on Fri, Oct. 31, 2003 
Pair plead guilty in Kenmore abuse
Women at mercy of court
By Phil Trexler Beacon Journal staff writer
As their eyes locked onto each other and swelled with tears, Mary Rowles whispered, ``I love you.''
In minutes, Rowles and her partner, Alice Jenkins, would embark on a journey that will undoubtedly end in a lengthy prison stay.
Just how long they will be incarcerated won't be learned until they are sentenced Dec. 10.
The Kenmore women, living together as a couple for seven years, avoided a trial that was supposed to start next week and pleaded guilty as charged Thursday to a 55-count indictment alleging they abused Rowles' six children.
They have now thrown themselves on the mercy of a Summit County judge who has already said 15 years in prison is not enough for what they did to the children.
The women pleaded guilty, their attorneys said, to avoid having Rowles' children testify about the abuse -- the dark, urine-soaked closet they were forced to live in for days and weeks, the kicks to the groin, the scant morsels of food they ate while kneeling at attention.
They also pleaded guilty, the attorneys said, because a conviction and lengthy prison sentence appeared inevitable. And a guilty verdict at trial on just three counts could have netted a possible 30-year prison term.
In the next six weeks, defense attorneys Don Malarcik and Kirk Migdal will focus on one issue: minimizing the sentence Judge Patricia A. Cosgrove can give their clients.
Theoretically, the women could be sentenced to more than 100 years in prison.
In the meantime, the women will undergo a presentence investigation that will touch on their personal history and their thoughts on the crimes they've admitted committing against the children, ages 6 to 14. Neither woman has a criminal history.
Prosecutors, meanwhile, will talk to the children's psychiatrists, counselors and foster families to show the court the devastation experienced by the children and the impact the crimes will have on their future.
``I've got to prepare for Dec. 10 as if it's the most important day in Mary's life,'' Migdal said. ``It's a daunting task because of the allegations. There are heartbreaking and inflammatory accusations here that involve children.''
Neither defense lawyers nor prosecutors would say how much prison time they will request from Cosgrove.
Chief Criminal Prosecutor Mary Ann Kovach said she would not be bound to the 15-year sentences the judge rejected last month. She said there were other restrictions required of the women had the plea agreement been approved.
Defense lawyers said the requirements include letters to the children from the women admitting their guilt and indicating the children did nothing to warrant the harsh punishment.
``I'm happy for the kids that they don't have to testify. That was our objective all along,'' Kovach said. ``But the plea bargain (offered in September) involved more than a particular amount of time.
``So, I want to see what happens between now and the time of sentencing. I want to see if certain things occur. At this point, there's no particular time we'll be seeking. But I certainly don't anticipate asking for less than 15 years.''
The children remain in two foster homes. Kovach said the kids are in school, are in counseling and have gained weight.  (REMAIN IN FOSTER HOMES BECAUSE FATHERS ARE UNFIT).
``They're a really great group of kids. They're resilient, their weights are up to where they should be, but we're still concerned about the long-term psychological effects,'' she said.
In April, three of the boys fled their Florida Avenue home in the middle of the night. After being picked up by Akron police officers, the children revealed a history of abuse at the hands of their mother and her domestic partner. The boys said they and their two brothers had been hit with a hammer, whipped with a belt, kicked in the groin and forced to eat animal feces over the past year. They said they were forced to sleep in a urine-saturated closet with no lights or windows.
Police said the boys were generally reprimanded for stealing food late at night, and the windowless closet was used as a punishment tool.
Their 12-year-old sister appeared to be well-fed and was not subjected to the same abuse, police said. She is still considered a victim in the indictments against Rowles and Jenkins.
Cosgrove nixed the 15-year plea agreement in September, telling attorneys she wanted to retain authority to sentence the women and the prison term that would have been imposed was not severe enough.
Malarcik, who represents Jenkins, said the women will write their children, expressing their remorse. He also said he hopes to put the acts into a context that might mitigate the crimes.
``I don't know that we can minimize what happened, but we want to put it into context and explain why this occurred as best we can. Certainly, there's no excuse, but there is a context in which these things occurred,'' he said.
``We hope the letters (from the women to the children) will assist in the children's healing process and indicate to them that they did nothing to warrant the punishment received.''
For now, Rowles and Jenkins will remain in the Summit County Jail without bond. Jenkins' bond was revoked after she pleaded guilty.
Rowles has been in jail since her arrest in May. Dressed in orange jail garb and cuffed at the ankles and wrists, she wept openly from the minute she laid eyes on Jenkins in court. She bounced on her toes and dabbed tears as she pleaded guilty to all the charges.
Jenkins' eyes were red when she entered the courtroom with her mother, Virginia, and brother and sister-in-law. She, too, openly cried as she admitted her guilt.
Jenkins had been free on bond all summer, but is now preparing for a lengthy stint in prison.
``I don't know if anyone, especially someone who has never been to prison, can realistically contemplate what a significant prison sentence is like,'' Migdal said. ``It obviously hit home today, but I don't know if you can fathom what it's like.'' 
I give the judge kudos for rejecting the plea agreement. 15 years doesn't seem like nearly enough time for someone who could do those things to any child, much less their own child.

Published: Sunday, 1/18/2004
The nightmare in Akron
Alice Jenkins and Mary Rowles are going away for a long, long time. But not nearly long enough.
The two women were sentenced last week in Summit County Common Pleas Court to 30 years in prison for their sadistic treatment of Rowles' six children.
What these monsters did, especially to the five boys, is almost beyond belief.
According to testimony, the boys were beaten, locked in a closet, denied food, and forced to eat animal waste and lick a dirty toilet bowl.
The eldest child, now 15, said at the sentencing that his so-called mother and her live-in companion would beat them on Christmas and then give them presents, only to destroy the gifts a few days later.
In previous testimony, taken after police in April found three of the severely malnourished boys walking the streets after they had escaped from the closet and dropped from a second-floor roof, the children told of having been hit with a hammer, whipped with a belt, kicked in the groin, and stabbed with a fork.
The two women initially pleaded guilty to 55 counts but later attempted to withdraw their pleas. Judge Patricia Cosgrove denied that request last week, and lawyers for the defendants are appealing, claiming that new evidence that shows the children, who were fathered by four men, suffer from a rare eating order.
The prosecution, however, points to the fact that one boy, who is 10 and appears to have borne the brunt of what it called "hate crimes, motivated by gender and racial bias," weighed only 41 pounds in April but now weighs more than 70 pounds.
Judge Cosgrove called the defendants, who laughed and talked before the hearing began, "the coldest, most unfeeling, least empathetic criminals I have ever seen."
It is difficult to accept that anyone could treat children the way these two women did unless there were some underlying cause such as a background of abuse or mental illness. In this case, however, we are inclined not to care.
During the sentencing, the eldest boy, who could not even bear to look at them, called his mother and her companion "hurtful people" and said "I don't want to see either of you ever again."

Attorneys argued in their appeals that the women should be allowed to withdraw their pleas. They also argued that Cosgrove's sentences exceeded the statutory maximum. The appellate court dismissed both claims in a 3-0 decision. The court ruled that Cosgrove's sentence was within Ohio's sentencing laws.

30-year sentences reimposed 
Judge says terms fair for two Kenmore women guilty of abusing six children 
Published: March 5, 2008 - 12:08 AM | Updated: June 17, 2011 - 03:53 PM
Thirty-year prison sentences were reimposed Tuesday on two Kenmore women convicted in 2003 of locking their children in a closet and other acts of violence and abuse. 
Mary Rowles, 35, and Alice Jenkins, 32, appeared before Summit County Common Pleas Judge Patricia A. Cosgrove for resentencing because of a 2006 Ohio Supreme Court ruling that found several facets of the state's criminal sentencing guidelines unconstitutional. 
But after both women and their lawyers made brief statements, Cosgrove ruled that their 30-year sentences were fair and appropriate, saying ''the pattern of cruelty and torture to six helpless children mandates a stiff penalty.'' 
''Quite frankly, what amount of time is a fair and appropriate punishment for these kinds of crimes?'' Cosgrove asked. 
''You deprived someone of food and water, you put your children in a closet, you won't let them go to the bathroom, they ate out of Dumpsters, they were filthy. How much time is enough time for having robbed these children of their childhood?'' 
Rowles and Jenkins, who lived together in a lesbian relationship, pleaded guilty in October 2003 to a 55-count indictment. Charges included kidnapping, felonious assault and endangering children. The indictment alleged that Rowles' five sons were the victims of numerous forms of abuse, ranging from frequent beatings to being locked in a dark closet for hours at a time to being deprived of food. The boys' sister also lived in the home. 
Before deciding the original sentences would stand, Cosgrove read from statements given by the children to police. 
Among the things the children told investigators were that they had been hit with a hammer, were made to lick a toilet seat because they had an accident on the floor and were forced to eat dog feces for misbehaving. 
Cosgrove said one of the children told police about being stabbed under the left eye with a fork. 
Jenkins asked the judge to reduce her sentence, saying she thought she deserved a second chance because she had worked hard in prison to better herself by regularly attending mental health counseling and working daily in a prison job making protective eye goggles. 
''I made mistakes -- bad mistakes,'' Jenkins said. ''But I'm just asking you to give me a second chance.'' 
Rowles, asking for no mercy, told the judge flatly: ''The children didn't have a second chance. We're right where we need to be.''

http://drcourt.org/wp/about/
The Summit County Domestic Relations Court has exclusive jurisdiction of bringing marriages to an end. This may be by divorce,dissolution or annulment. The control of the Court continues until all the children born to the parties have reached age eighteen and no longer regularly attend high school. In addition,the Court has the power to enforce all its orders,even years after the end of the marriage. In Summit County,the Domestic Relations Court also has jurisdiction over all matters involving custody,visitation and support of minor children,unless they are already wards of another court (i.e. Juvenile Court Dependency/Neglect/Abuse cases). The Court also shares, with the Municipal Court and the Common Pleas Court,jurisdiction over domestic violence cases. DR COURT DEALS WITH DIVORCE, DISSOLUTION OR ANNULMENT & ALL MATTERS INVOLVING CUSTODY,VISITATION AND SUPPORT OF MINOR CHILDREN (VISITATION PERTAINING TO THE DR COURT ORDERS,NOT OTHER COURTS). Police received reports Monday that three boys from the home were wandering in the streets, wearing sweat pants and T-shirts but no shoes or socks. The oldest boy told authorities he had gotten rags from a garbage can and wrapped them on his feet because they were sore from walking without shoes. The boys said they ran away from home because their mother and her partner had locked them in a closet for months,letting them out each day for dinner only. They said the women blocked the closet door with a dresser when the boys were inside. The closet was always dark inside,was hot and smelled of urine and feces. When police arrived at the home to remove the other children,they found the 6-year-old boy locked in a bedroom that smelled of urine and feces. The children also told authorities they suffered beatings,according to the complaint. Two of the boys reported that their mother's partner forced some of the children to hold the 10-year-old boy down while she kicked him in the groin with steel-toed boots after she accused him of urinating in the closet. In November,CSB received a report concerning the welfare of the children,but nobody visited the home until February. (CSB DROPPED THE BALL,AGAIN NOT THE DR COURT) Three of the boys have been placed in a foster home and the two boys in the hospital will join them. The girl is in a separate foster home. (WHY A FOSTER HOME? WHERE ARE THE BOY'S FATHERS & POSTLETHWAITES,FATHER/STEP OF THE GIRL?) The next court hearing is May 23. At that time the court will determine whether the children have been abused or neglected. It's unclear whether the social worker who visited the home believed an investigation should be opened. The agency requires workers and their supervisors to make that decision together. (TAKES 2 PEOPLE AT THE CSB TO RECOMMEND A INVESTIGATION. WHEN THEY DID INVESTIGATE,EVERYTHING APPEARED TO BE FINE). Miller said the agency should have acted before this week. post_title: Charges Filed In 'One Of The Largest' Food Stamp Frauds EVER
post_text:
-Charges Filed In 'One Of The Largest' Food Stamp Frauds EVER
The FBI has filed charges against dozens of people in Georgia who allegedly set up a scheme that funneled $18 million worth of food stamps through grocery stores in what a Department of Justice official is calling "one of the largest federal food program frauds ever."
Fifty-four people were indicted for their roles in the massive fraud which involved the illegal purchase of WIC and food stamp benefits.
The fraud "allegedly involved the purchase of more than $18 million in WIC vouchers and Food Stamp benefits for cash through a number of purported grocery stores set up throughout Georgia."
Another 34 defendants were indicted for selling their benefits. Through the WIC program, participants receive 3-month supplies of vouchers which can be exchanged for food at authorized stores. The Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program (SNAP) provides food stamp benefits to low-income families.
It is illegal to sell WIC and SNAP benefits for cash, though that did not stop the 88 people involved in the scam.
"Many of the defendants allegedly canvassed low-income neighborhoods and solicited WIC and Food Stamp participants to illegally exchange their benefits not for food but for cash," the DOJ's charge reads.
After setting up grocery store operations throughout Georgia, the defendants bought the benefits for a fraction of their face value.
The defendants then allegedly laundered the $18 million they received from the scheme.
Another 34 defendants who were charged separately allegedly sold over $1,000 worth of WIC and food stamps for cash.
"This prosecution is one of the largest federal food program frauds ever brought," said U.S. Attorney Edward J. Tarver in a statement.
The 54 defendants were charged with one count each of mail and wire fraud conspiracy and money laundering conspiracy. The charges carry a maximum sentence of up to 20 years in prison.
The government seeks the forfeiture of $20 million in bank accounts and assets, including two luxury vehicles, a 2008 Mercedes Benz and a 2008 Land Rover. Defendants began appearing in federal court on Tuesday and will continue to appear on Wednesday.
http://news.yahoo.com/charges-filed-one-largest-food-stamp-frauds-ever-023605531.html

post_title: Colorado Restaurant Wants Customers, Employees To Carry Guns
post_text:
Shooters Grill in Rifle, Colorado, not only allows customers and employees to carry guns in the restaurant, they go out of their way to encourage it.
According to the Post Independent, a sign on the front of the restaurant reads: "Guns are welcome on premises. Please keep all weapons holstered, unless the need arises. In such cases, judicious marksmanship is appreciated."
Guns are carried openly by waitresses and patrons alike. 
The restaurant is owned by Lauren Boebert who says: "We encourage [carrying guns], and the customers love that they can come here and express their rights. This country was founded on our freedom. People can come in carrying their gun, and they can pray over their food." 
Boebert says she "consulted with [her] Christian friends and everyone" before opening the restaurant just over a year ago. And while some expressed concern that a place named "'Shooters' sounded like a bar or strip joint," she concluded that the restaurant was fitting because Rifle was "founded on guns and the Old West."
http://www.breitbart.com/Big-Government/2014/06/29/Colorado-Restaurant-Wants-Customers-Employees-To-Carry-Guns

post_title: Missouri Trains Teachers to Concealed Carry at School
post_text:
Missouri Trains Teachers to Concealed Carry at School
School shootings have become an effective political tool in the hands of liberals who are chomping at the bit for an excuse to repeal the Second Amendment and ban guns across the country, a fact that is both irreverent and disgusting.
Rather than looking for legitimate ways to improve safety at public schools and college campuses, liberals in Congress draft legislation that strips law-abiding citizens of their right to own a gun to protect themselves and their families.
Many law enforcement officers have made it clear that they won't be enforcing gun bans, doing their duty to protect the constitutional rights of those they serve.
Banning guns and requiring strict gun control measures has proven to be completely ineffective at keeping children safe at school. Criminals don't buy their weapons from gun shops, they get them from the black market, so gun control laws only serve to help criminals in their illegal activities.
Missouri is taking a different approach to improving school safety, one that is sure to have the hair on the back of Hillary Clinton's neck standing on end. Several school districts are training teachers how to use concealed weapons.
    Some Missouri school districts have decided the best way to thwart a massacre like the Sandy Hook shooting in 2012 is to train teachers to carry concealed weapons in the classroom.
    For a $17,500 fee, districts get 40 hours of training on how to use a Glock 19 semi-automatic pistol for two staffers at a hilltop range in the Ozarks town of West Plains, the Kansas City Star reported. Instructors are current law enforcement officers with Shield Solutions.
    The company's founder, Greg Martin, told the Star only school district administrators and local law enforcement will know the identity of the teachers trained to pack heat.
    "Like air marshals on planes," Martin told the newspaper. "How many hijackings have we had since 9/11?"
    Ten Missouri school districts have signed up for Shield Solutions training; three more have signed contracts.
Good. Allowing teachers to be armed in the classroom is something that should've been done years ago, after the first big school shooting in Columbine. How many lives could have been saved had these measures been taken then?
The fact that teachers will be trained with the proper use of firearms will not only provide an instant resource to help stop a shooting in progress, but it will act as a deterrent for any students who might be contemplating a rampage of their own.
More schools across the country need to be enrolled in this kind of program in order to provide adequate safety for children in the classroom.
Read more at http://conservativetribune.com/teachers-concealed-carry/#voPjxAAiazY1zPly.99
